She has engaged in this business since 1996 and has built up a stable and successful operation over many years. In the future she hopes to continue to operate her business at a sustainable level. She plans to buy a large amount of clothing items at wholesale prices in order to sell those items as a retailer in December. She is a modest and hardworking woman. She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase and import winter clothes such as suits, coats, outerwear etc from China in order to increase her working capital for her business.

loans.use: To purchase and import winter clothes

loans.name: Razel

texts.en:
Razel A., from the village of Mapuroc San Mateo, is 35 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Razel has owned and operated a general store selling a variety of products in the local community for over six years, earning approximately 1400 PHP a month.

In 2010, Razel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Batsaihan

texts.en:
Batsaihan C. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Arhangai Province of Mongolia. His two oldest sons attend a local high school, while his wife operates a construction business in the summer months. Batsaihan has timber trading and transportation businesses in his town.

Batsaihan started his transportation business between Arhangai and Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia, in 1998 after purchasing a Russian jeep. He started his business with 450,000 MNT of working capital which has since grown to 6,000,000 MNT. After many years of successful operation, he was able to replace his vehicle with a much larger larger truck for 8,500,000 MNT.

Batsaihan, a very friendly man who has gained much experience both as a driver and businessman, is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to enhance his transportation business.

loans.use: To enhance his transportation business

loans.name: Ulziiburen

texts.en:
Ulziiburen S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in her sister's house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Both of her sons attend a secondary school, while her husband operates a meat trading business after having sold their house. Ulziiburen operates both a dairy products and a newspaper trading business in a rented stall at the grocery shop next to the bus station of Bayanzurh district.

In 2000, after moving from the countryside, she started her business by selling a variety of goods in Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar's largest and main market. After many years of operation, she has built a stable and successful operation. For the future, Ulziiburen plans to have her own grocery shop. A modest and open-minded person who says, “All I want is to have our own apartment where my family can live in a comfortable space, ” she is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more dairy products and fruits to sell at her stall for profit.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products and fruits to sell

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon P. is from the village of Mapuroc San Mateo. She is 28 years old. Sharon is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Sharon owns and operates a transportation business, providing motorcycle transport. Sharon has been engaged in her business for more than eight years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Sharon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Sharon is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the first loan taken by Sharon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia D. A. is a married woman who lives in 110, Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a food-vending business and a farm. Her husband, Cornelio, who is 58 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 21 and 40 years old. 

Delia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Delia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15000, with which she intends to buy stock for the general store and fertilizers for her rice and corn plantation so that she can continue to save for future improvements to the businesses. 

Delia D. A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: 28 -Cho- Dien Bien Group

texts.en:
Lan T. T. (127) is a 49 year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Lan is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 28 -Cho- Dien Bien (03.01.28 Dien Bien).

Lan is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, Lan runs a food stall. Lan has been engaged in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Lan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4248000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 5310000 VND, which also will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken by Lan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. 

About the other borrowers in the group:
1.  N. T. Hoa (125) is a 61-year-old woman who is requesting a 5310000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

2.  L. T. Tinh (126) is a 56-year-old woman who is requesting a 5310000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3.  H. T. Loan (124) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 5310000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of  Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Lan T. T. (127) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Lan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 28-Cho - Dien Bien (03.01.28 Dien Bien).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Lan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Lan kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Lan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Lan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.248.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. T. Hoa (125) là 61 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  L. T. Tinh (126) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


3.  H. T. Loan (124) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: 27-Cho-Dien Bien Group

texts.en:
Binh N. T. (129) is a 55-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Binh is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 27-Cho-Dien Bien (03.01.27-Cho-Dien Bien).

Binh is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Binh buy and resell general products such as suger, vermicelli... to local community members.  Binh has been engaged in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Binh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation.  Binh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,248,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,310,000 VND, which also will be used to invest in expanding the business. This  will be the second loan taken by Binh from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. 

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  N. T. Luan (128) is a 52-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

2.  N. T. Lien (131) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector in retail blankets, sheets, pillows, cushions...

3.  N. T. Dung (130) is a 45-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in operateing a store selling paper votice objects

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund foro Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

Binh N. T. (129) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Binh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 27 Cho Dien Bien (03.01.27-cho-Dien Bien).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ hàng khô cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Binh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Binh kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Binh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Binh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.248.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. T. Luan (128) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  N. T. Lien (131) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chăn, ga, gối đệm.


3.  N. T. Dung (130) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hàng mã.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita G. is a married woman who lives in 111, Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a sugarcane plantation and rice field. Her husband, John Glenn, who is 42 years old, works as a heavy equipment operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.They have three children who are between 7 and 19 years old. 

Nenita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1993 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nenita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 16600, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 24500, which she intends to use for additional capital for the sugarcane plantation so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Nenita G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 	

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To use as capital for  the sugarcane plantation

loans.name: Masrur

texts.en:
Masrur owns a small kiosk and sells household supplies at the central city market. He started this business three years ago. The goods he sells are in high demand and his business is going well. Masrur is a hard-working person and he would like to develop his business even more. Masrur would like to get a loan of $1500 USD to increase the inventory. He hopes that this loan will be another small step in his business growth. Masrur's goal is to have a stable source of income for his family.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history. It was a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita D., from the village of Rizal West San Isidro, is 58 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Warlita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector directly selling Avon products. Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Warlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having  repaid her previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting her fourth loan for 13000 PHP for the same purpose.  Warlita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Las Flores Al Progeso Group

texts.es:
Aquilina es una mujer muy trabajadora tiene 07 hijos de los cuales 3 aun son pequeños es por ellos a sus 49 años sigue luchando para sacarlos adelante, ella siempre ha trabajado en el rubro de comidas, durante mucho tiempo se dedico a preparar almuerzos para los trabajadores de varias fabricas, lamentablemente el trayecto de su casa al trabajo era muy largo y cansado, por estar mas tiempo con sus hijos  pequeños es que decide dejar el trabajo para empezar a trabajar en su propia bodega la que inicia en su misma casa, con algunos  ahorros los préstamos de EDAPROSPO empezó su negocio ella recuerda que al principio solo vendía algunos productos y algunas cosas que ella misma preparaba como picarones, mazamorras (dulces peruanos) ella esta feliz de pertenecer al grupo “LAS FLORES AL PROGRESO” por que ha sido un impulso muy grande para lograr sus metas, en la actualidad su negocio aparte de crecer ha mejorado esta mas  surtido con productos variados, esto la llena de orgullo pues considera que es un logro. Además que esto le sirve para ayudar con la educación de sus hijos y vivir mejor  por otro lado también pudo  invertir su dinero en la compra de su propio terreno ahora se proyecta a construirlo y poner un minimarket,  su préstamo lo usara para comprar productos navideños que se vende por esta época como panetones, champang, chocolates etc. 

*La Sra. Aquilina esta con polo amarillo y pantalón celeste.
texts.en:
Aquilina is a very hard working woman.  She has 7 children, three of whom are still little.  It’s for them that at the age of 49 she continues to work to support them.

She has always worked in the food business.  For a long time she prepared lunch for employees at several factories.  Unfortunately, the trip from home to work was very long and tiring so, in order to spend more time with her small children, she left that job to start working in her own grocery store that she installed in her house.

With some savings and EDAPROSPO loans she started the business.  She remembers that at the beginning she only sold a few products and some things that she herself prepared like picarones (type of fried donut) and mazamorra (maize based Peruvian sweet).  

She is happy to be part of the “LAS FLORES AL PROGRESO” (Flowers to Progress) group because it’s been a push for her to reach her goals.  Currently the business has grown and improved; it is stocked with a greater variety of items.  This fills her with pride because she considers this quite the accomplishment in addition to it serving as a means for her to educate her children and live better.  Also, she was able to invest money in the purchase of a lot and is now planning to build a minimarket on it.

She will use the loan to buy assorted Christmas products that are sold during this season like, Panettones, champagne, chocolates, etc.

*Aquilina is wearing the yellow shirt and sky blue pants.

loans.use: To buy Panettones and liquor for her store.

texts.en:
Mrs. Ethel D. is from Guba, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old and is married with three school-age children. She is the group leader of this four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Ethel D. Group. 

Ethel owns and operates a business of making and selling food, such as snacks and other delicacies, in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for ten years and earns approximately $72 a month.

In 2005, Ethel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC.

Ethel is now requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 12th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About PMPC: 
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. 
About Group Loans
In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.name: Imarika Group

texts.en:
Mandela R., in black in the back row, is in his mid twenties and is married with one daughter. He has been running a charcoal business for the past four years. The business is open between 06:00 am and 06:00 pm and earns him a small monthly profit.

This will be Mandela's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He aims to use the loan to expand his business, mainly by increasing his stock of charcoal to meet customer demand. He hopes this will increase his profit and make him the biggest charcoal seller in his part of the town, and to start selling wholesale.

Mandela will share this loan with his loan group Imarika, which has 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

loans.use: Increase his stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarah R. is from the village of Garang, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old, married to Glecirio R., Jr. and blessed with 2 children who are both still in school. To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store. She’s been engaged in this kind of retailing business for 2 years already. At present she is earning an amount of not less than Php 3,000 from the sales of this business. 

Just this year, Sarah joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, Sarah is now requesting a loan of Php 25,000 as her 1st loan which will be used as additional capital for her existing sari-sari store business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, children’s education expenses, and possible business expansion.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing sari-sari store business

location.town: Silanga, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Kimgugi Group

texts.en:
Sara K. is in her early twenties and is single with a baby son. For the past year, Sara has a small fabric and clothing business and she walks door to door selling fabric and young women’s clothing. Sara works daily from 10:00 am to 8:00 pm and earns a low monthly profit.

This will be Sara’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. Sara successfully repaid her first loan that was used to increase her stock of fabric and clothing. With her second loan, Sara will increase her stock in order to increase sales. Her dream is to one day have a big shop where she can sell her products. 

In this picture, Sara is in the front row, holding the baby. Sara will share this loan with her 15-member loan group “Kimgugi.” The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying their loan.

loans.use: to buy fabric and used clothing

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma D. is from the village of Panalsalan. She is 49 years old. Alma is widowed and has 2 children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a furniture-making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 19 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Alma is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Alma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

Leonora operates a family member's business in the food sector, making & selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials for house completion. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Leonora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Mavlon

texts.ru: Чорикулов Мавлон проживает в районе Кубодиён. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат. Имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается строительными работами по найму. Кроме того он более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений и топлива, чтобы посеет и получить хороший урожай.
texts.en: Mavlon C. lives in Qubadiyon.  He is 36 years old, married, and has five children.  He has a high school education.  He is a day laborer in construction.  Additionally, he has been working in agriculture for six years.  He has a plot of land at his home where he grows vegetables.  He is taking out a loan to buy mineral fertilizers and fuel in order to plant and to receive a good harvest.

loans.use: buying mineral fertilizers and fuel

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Mrs. Delia S. is from the village of Labuyo, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old, married and blessed with 3 children of whom two are still at school and the other one is now at work. To make a living, she is presently engaged in dried fish vending business. She’s been engaged in this kind of retailing business for 2 years already. This time she is earning an amount of not less than Php 2,500 from the sales of this business.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, children’s education expenses, and possible business expansion.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora L. is from the village of Mahinog, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 60 years old, separated from her spouse, and has three adult children. To make a living, Aurora owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling of fruits and green bananas in the local community. Aurora has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Aurora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Aurora is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional green bananas. This loan will be Aurora's sixth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green bananas

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben S., 50, is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase wood to produce wooden doors and windows to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. 

S. and her husband sell wooden doors and windows, earning an income of USD 2 each per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known for being well-supplied with fresh water from major rivers. The family has to spend USD 40 on food, USD 3 on electricity supply, and USD 23 on other necessary expenses every month. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy wood to produce wooden doors and windows to sell

loans.name: Togtuur

texts.en:
Togtuur D. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Selenge province, Mongolia. The family lives in the house of her husband's parents who both passed away. Her two sons attend a local secondary school and her husband works as a driver in his town. 

Togtuur operates a consumer goods trading business at a local market. She began her consumer goods sales business in 2006 after operating a grocery products trading business which was started in 2003. In addition, she purchases a variety of food products from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia and transports them back to her town in order to sell those products through grocery shops as a wholesaler. 

After years of successful operation, she has gained significant experience as a businesswoman. For the future, she plans to expand her business and have her own workplace. Togtuur is a hard-working woman and says, "I want to buy or build my own house and fence where my family can live in the future." She requesting a 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes A. is a widow who lives in 109, Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  general store and buying & selling charcoal & vegetables businesses. Lourdes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lourdes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, with which she intends to buy stock for the general store and charcoal to sell so that she can continue to save up for future improvement of her business. Lourdes A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon G. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Corazon is separated from her spouse and has 8 children. To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables like stringbeans & eggplant & also spices in the local community. She also makes and sells a variety of dishes like fried chicken & pork adobo in the local community. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Corazon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients for cooking viands. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Corazon from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva N. is 38 years old, married, and supports her family by operating two business ventures: buying & selling ready-to-wear clothing and farming (sugarcane plantation) businesses. She lives in 111, Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her buying & selling of ready-to-wear clothes and farming (sugarcane plantation) businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 14,700. Eva is now borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she can continue to purchase more clothes to sell.  This will be her 4th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Eva aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Joefemia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Joefemia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Liberty

texts.en:
Liberty M. is a married woman who lives in 112 Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a buying and selling ready-to-wear clothes business, and a farming (sugarcane) business. Her husband, Agapito, who is 56 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's businesses. They have 12 children aged between 5 and 30.
Liberty joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Liberty has been gradually lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 9,000 PHP, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing 12,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy stocks for the general store and fertilizer for her sugarcane. Liberty wants to continue to save up for the future education of her children and to improve her business. Liberty M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Batochir

texts.en:
Batochir J. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent and fence. His two sons attend a local school. His wife operates a clothes trading business which was started in 2007 out of a rented shipping container in her town.

 Batochir manages a transportation business, transporting people and loads between local towns. He rents a bus to use for transportation. He has been engaged this business since 2008 and has gained significant experience as a driver.

 Batochir is a very talkative man and says, "My business goal is to buy a mini-bus for my business." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to repair his rent car and purchase more clothes for his wife's business.

loans.use: To repair his rented vehicle and purchase more clothing for his wife's business

loans.name: Agatona

texts.en:
Agatona N. is from the village of Benoni, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Agatona is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Agatona owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling confectionery products like "pastel", "pop rice" & "otap" in the local community. Agatona has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Agatona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agatona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Agatona is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like "pastel" & "pop rice". This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Agatona from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Fevie

texts.en:
Fevie R. lives in Prk. Pajo, Brgy. Lawaan I, Talisay, Cebu. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a cabinet manufacturing business. Her common-law husband Reynanto Fernandez, who is 32 years old, works as a cabinetmaker to earn his living. She has 4 children who are between 3 and 12 years old.

 Fevie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 3 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Fevie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 4th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase materials for furniture-making so that she can continue to save up for the future of her children and for family needs. 

Fevie R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Hakob

texts.en:
Hakob A. is 47 years old; he lives in Tsovaghugh village, Sevan area, with his wife and his two sons. He has technical education and for several years Hakob worked with a bus fleet as a mechanic. Since 1996 Hakob and his family are engaging in animal breeding. 

In his farm Hakob breeds cows and calves, sheep and chickens. Hakob’s family works very hard and thanks to this fact they support their family and were able to buy a truck, which they use for fodder transportation. 

Hakob is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy some calves for his farm.

loans.use: To buy some calves for his farm

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira T. is a 44-year-old widow who supports her family by operating one business venture: curtain & bed sheets business. She lives in Prk. Antipolo, Brgy. Linao, Talisay, Cebu City. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her curtain & bed sheets business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Elvira is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can purchase materials for tailoring. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elvira aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en:
Marvin S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 29 years old. Marvin is married and has 3 children aged 10, 9 and 8. To make a living, Marvin owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Marvin joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marvin has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Marvin is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and seeds. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.name: Otgonsuren

texts.en: Otgonsuren D. is 51 years old and lives with her husband in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. She and her husband live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Otgonsuren operates a meat retail business in her town. She began her business in 2005 with working capital of 150,000 MNT. After several years of hard work to build a loyal customer base, her working capital now exceeds 700,000 MNT. Otgonsuren purchases meat from herders and sells it at the local market as a retailer. Her earnings have enabled her to buy her own livestock for her family. Otgonsuren is a hardworking and honest woman. She is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase meat

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
Rolando M. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is single and 38 years old. To make a living, Rolando owns and operates a specialized retail store. His main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling coconuts in the local community, and he also buys and sells soft drinks. Rolando has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

Rolando joined HSPFI in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolando has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. For his second loan, he is requesting 4,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as coconuts. Roland plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve and expand.

loans.name: Luy

texts.en: The woman in the photo is Mrs. Luy V., age 50, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. She has run this business since 2000. She is married with four children, two of whom are single and two of whom are married. Two of her children share their salary with her every month. Her husband helps her in raising pigs and also works as a farmer. Dry weather is expected in the beginning of this year, and it may affect Mrs. Luy V.’s husband's business. Her husband faces a difficult season if he is not able to irrigate his crops. Mrs. Luy V. is taking out a loan for her husband to purchase a machine that he uses to pump water for his crops.

loans.use: To purchase a machine to pump water for crops.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 47 years old. Nancy is married and has two children aged 19 and 18. To make a living, Nancy plants and harvests rice to sell. Nancy works hard to help improve her family's living conditions. 

Nancy needs fertilizers and other farm supplies. She applied for a loan of PHP 20000 from CEVI, a KIVA partner. She will use the loan to buy the farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children. She owns a small farming business growing tomatoes in greenhouses. Irina has been in this business for 7 years. During this time she has built six large greenhouses where she plants about 7,000 tomatoes.

Irina is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnas to purchase additional film for some greenhouses. It will allow her to plant tomatoes earlier and keep them warm in the cold spring. The earlier Irina harvests the tomatoes, the higher the price. Irina hopes to increase her sales and invest the extra income back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional film for her greenhouses

loans.name: C5528 Abanyamurava Group

texts.en:
Josephine, a 30-year-old married mother of five children between the ages of 2 and 12, is the leader of the group called Abanyamurava. This group consists of nine members: two men and seven women.

Josephine, with five years of experience selling milk, conducts her business between 7 a.m and 6 p.m. daily. Hoping to earn more profits which will allow her to save money for the future, feed her family and pay school fees for her children, she has requested a loan to purchase a large quantity of milk.

loans.use: To purchase more milk

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia A., from the town of Sto. Niño, is 33 years old, married, and has four children, her eldest only eight years old. To make a living, Nemia owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale. She works hard to improve her family's living conditions.

Nemia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Mrs. Eng K., 41, and her husband, 38, currently live in Kompong Tom Province. Eng earns a living by raising pigs both for their offspring and for slaughter in a pigpen behind her house. She has a life partner in her husband, a local farmer, and they have five children, three single, one studying in university, and the other two married; they also work with her in pig raising. Because Eng's account is not sufficient to pay her child's school fees, she  is requesting a loan from Kiva for that purpose.

loans.use: To pay her child's school fees

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel, a 42-year-old married farmer with four children, plants and harvests rice crops in Sto. Niño, Agusan Del Sur, where most people are involved in farming. He works hard to provide for his family and improve their living conditions. Noel chose to plant rice because it is easier to sell compared to other crops. He also makes sure to sell quality rice to the local community.

Because he needs farm inputs such as fertilizers, Noel has applied for a loan of PHP20000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a KIVA partner in the Philippines.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as fertilizers

loans.name: C5507 Duterimbere Group

texts.en:
Ernestine, a 26-year-old married mother of three children between the ages of two and six, is the president of a group called Duterimbere, and she has her hand raised in the picture above. This is her fourth successful year in the business of selling fish, and she works everyday from 7 a.m. until 8 p.m.

Ernestine has requested a loan to purchase more fish to sell. With the use of this loan, Ernestine and her team expect to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow each member of the group to start saving as well as building a better future for their families.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene J. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 44 years old and sells fish to earn a living. Rene owns a motorcycle that he uses to go around his town and sell fish. He buys directly from fishermen and therefore can get a lower price. 

Rene wants to improve his business and increase his earnings. He has applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP from CEVI to buy more fish to sell. Rene is still paying for his motorcycle and he hopes to earn enough money to pay it off in full.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna D. is from the village of Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 53 years old, widowed, and has four adult children. To make a living, Edna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, and other foods in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Edna is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell including beverages and other foods. This loan will be Edna's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Ma. Socorro's Group

texts.en:
Ma. Socorro A. is from the village of Carabatan Chica, Cauayan City, Isabela. Ma. Socorro is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ma. Socorro is 37 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Socorro owns and operates a  general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Ma. Socorro is just starting this business.

In 2010, Ma. Socorro joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Socorro has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ma. Socorro is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Ma. Socorro's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El E., 56, is a village woman living in Takhmao city, Cambodia. She is a local crop farmer, growing rice, and vegetables on her own farmland. To help meet the family's daily needs, her husband works with her in the farming business as well. She raises pigs behind her house in order to earn additional income to support her family. She is married with five children; two are single and two others are employed as garment workers in a factory. 

Unfortunately, her pigs are not big enough, due to lack of food. To help solve this problem, El E. would like to request a loan that she will use to buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs and to buy more small pigs to raise.

loans.use: To buy many sacks of pig feed  and  more small pigs to raise

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Merlyn T. is from the village P2 Gotokan Daku, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, married and blessed with 2 children, both still minors. To make a living, she is presently engaged in farming, particularly in banana production. She’s been engaged in this kind of agricultural activity for 3 years already. She is also receiving regular support from her husband as a motorcycle driver. She’s earning an average amount of not less than P 2,000 a month from her agricultural activity. 

On July 31, 2007 Merlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  As a active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities, Merlyn has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php 10,000. She is now requesting a loan of Php 40,000 as her 6th loan to be used for purchasing am additional second-hand motorcycle for business purposes. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, children’s education expenses, and possible business expansion.

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en:

The members of this group all sell fish for a living. This is Marie Louise's second successful year in her business, which employs one other person and is open from 8am-10pm every day.

Marie Louise has requested a loan to buy more fish for her business.  With this loan, she hopes to earn more profits to continue to invest in the business.

To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a bakeshop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from baking & selling a variety of staple products including bread in the local community. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Mrs. Judith A. is from the village of Garang, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married to Sanler A. and blessed with one child who is still a minor. To make a living, she is presently engaged in milk fish ("bangus") culture and rice production. She’s been engaged in this kind of agricultural activity for 5 years already. At present she is earning an amount of not less than Php 30,000 per quarter from the sale of her harvest. 

In the year 2009, Judith joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, Judith has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php 47,000. She is now requesting a loan of Php 30,000 as her 4th loan which will be used as additional capital for purchasing feed for her existing "bangus" culture and  the remaining amount for commercial fertilizers for rice production. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, her child’s education expenses, and possible future land acquisition.

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Khoeng

texts.en: Khoeng K. is 38 and the father of three school-aged kids. Khoeng K. and his wife now live in Phnom Penh City.  Khoeng K. earns his income as a fish trader in the busy market with his wife. This couple always buys fresh fish in bulk from fisherman in the rural area, and then they sell it to gain daily income.  Generally, Khoeng K. used his old motorbike for picking up his product to take to the market, but it broke while driving. He wants to buy a new one, but his personal savings are insufficient. So Khoeng K. would like a loan in order to buy new motorcycle to replace the broken one, and with the rest buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to replace the broken one, and use the rest to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anacita

texts.en:
Anacita O. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Anacita is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Anacita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Her husband is a fisherman, and Anacita sells the fish he catches. Anacita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Anacita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anacita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Anacita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  Some of the funds will be used to maintain their boat.  This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Anacita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen A. O. is twenty eight years old. She is married.  Her husband is a teacher, and they have two children, aged ten years old and five years old. Her business is located at a busy market in Kisumu known as Dago market. She has a grocery stand at which she sells such items as vegetables, tomatoes, onions and fish. She has been in this business for five years now and she says that this business is profitable .  The only major challenge she has is the long distance she walks in search of wholesalers from whom she purchases the items she sells. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She will use her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy cabbages, tomatoes and onions to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. In the future, she hopes to grow her business to wholesale and provide employment to people through her business. She describes herself as obedient, disciplined and a risk taker.

loans.use: Cabbages, tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Athanase

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwanda!  Athanase is 40 years old and is married, with two children who are 4 and 8 years old.  He owns a small general store and employs one person.

Athanase has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to help expand his business by purchasing a large quantity of sugar and rice, as they are in high demand. He has lots of plans for any profits that he makes from the business.  These include renovating his house, paying school fees for his two children, as well as building a secure future for his children.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity  of sugar and rice.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.
